title-group.article-title: On the physical interpretation of the M-integral in nonlinear elastic defect mechanics

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Structural Strength and Vibration, School of Aerospace, Xi’an Jiaotong University, P.R. China
2School of Civil Engineering and Architecture, Xi’an University of Technology, Xi’an, P.R. China

author-notes.corresp: Q Li, State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Structural Strength and Vibration, School of Aerospace, Xi’an Jiaotong University, P.R. China. Email: qunli@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Several properties of the M-integral are clarified within the context of nonlinear elastic defect mechanics. A material damage expansion force vector associated with the integrand of the M-integral is derived by divergence vector operation of the Lagrangian energy density moment. It is concluded that the components of damage expansion force vector are indentified as the change of potential energy due to the self-similar expansion of one infinitesimal material element along the x1 or x2 direction. Subsequently, the physical interpretation of the M-integral over the contour enclosing all defects is explored in nonlinear elasticity containing multiple defects by an explicit analysis. The explicit analysis reveals that the M-integral is inherently related to the change of the total potential energy during the formation of defects from the initial non-damaged system in addition to the nonlinear strain energy within the area enclosed by integration contour.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the past several decades, the J-integral as introduced by Rice (1986) has been widely used in fracture mechanics for the analysis of crack problems in both linear elastic and nonlinear elastic-plastic materials (Budiansky and Rice, 1973; Carka and Landis, 2011; Eischen and Herrmann, 1987; Kienzler and Herrmann, 1997; McMeeking, 1977). The integrand of the J-integral is prominently relevant with the most famous Eshelby tensor (Eshelby, 1951, 1975), which can be derived by considering the gradient of Lagrangian density (Eischen and Herrmann, 1987; Kienzler and Herrmann, 1997). The Eshelby tensor theory is even designed as Mechanics in Material Space by contrast to the traditional Newtonian Mechanics. Relying on similar manipulation by Noether’s theorem (Noether, 1971), an additional damage expansion force vector by considering the divergence vector operation of the Lagrangian moment can be established, which subsequently associated with the M-integral of linear elasticity (Budiansky and Rice, 1973; Knowles and Stermberg, 1972). The M-integral is of practical importance in defect mechanics to predict the multiple defect stability and growth (Chang and Chien, 2002; Chang and Peng, 2004; Chen, 2001a, 2001b; King and Herrmann, 1981; Ma et al., 2001). Particularly, the M-integral is found to be inherently related to the change of the total potential energy for a 2D linear damaged elasticity regardless of the detailed damage characterizations. A problem-invariant parameter Mc (the critical value of the M-integral) can be possibly proposed as a possible damage parameter for describing the degradation of material and structural integrity caused by irreversible evolution of multiple defects. All studies demonstrated that the M-integral is emerged as a damage criterion to be capable of describing the damage behavior of a multi-damaged mechanical system similar as the J-integral in fracture mechanics as a fracture criterion. Furthermore, it can provide some outside variable features that might open a new technique or framework to evaluate material damage evolution.

However, to the present author’s knowledge, the M-integral mentioned above was limited in linear elasticity and no one in the open literature had considered the properties of the M-integral within the context of nonlinear elastic defect mechanics. Particularly, the real physical meaning of the M-integral in nonlinear elasticity containing multiple defects is obscure, which restricts the wider application of the M-integral. For the purpose, this study attempts to fill that gap and clarifies several physical properties corresponding to the M-integral by an explicit analysis. Two concepts of “material damage expansion force” and “material damage expansion source” are introduced and the balance conservation between them is established. The derivation of the M-integral is explored by the damage expansion force vector which is associated with the integrand of the M-integral and deduced by subjecting the Lagrangian density to the familiar divergence operation. The traditional definition of the M-integral is reviewed by using the concept of damage expansion force while the alternative expression of the M-integral is introduced through the material damage expansion source by an explicit form. Moreover, the real physical interpretation of the damage expansion force and the M-integral are explicitly investigated. The present exploration of various properties of the M-integral is to supply the lack of investigation of conservation law in nonlinear elasticity. It indeed facilitates the better understanding of the M-integral as a potential framework to evaluate material damage evolution in nonlinear elasticity.

sec.title: Material damage expansion force vector and the M-integral
sec.p: The components of the infinitesimal strain tensor in an elastic solid are (1)ɛkj=12(uk,j+uj,k), where uk denotes the components of displacements; the subscript prima{}’i refers to the corresponding differentiation with respect to the coordinate xi; the repeated indices denote summation over the range of indices in the following.

The strain energy density is introduced by (2)W(xi,ɛkj(xi))=∫ɛkjσkjdɛkj, which can be separated into the linear part (WL) and the nonlinear one (WNL) parts for the nonlinear elastic material under a monotonic increasing loading (3)W=WL+WNL, with (4)WL=12σkjɛkj=12σkjuk,j.
The Cauchy stress tensor σkj is then given by (5)σkj=∂W∂ɛkj.
Due to symmetry of the stress tensor, an alternative way of equation (5) is written as (6)σkj=∂W∂uk,j.
Likewise, by introducing an external potential of (7)V(xi,uk(xi))=-∫ukfkduk in a conservative loading system, the body force fk per unit volume has (8)fk=-∂V∂uk
The divergence of stress tensor and the body force are connected through the balance of momentum, i.e., the equilibrium condition (9)σkj,j+fk=0.

For an isotropic nonlinear elastic material under a monotonic increasing tensile loading or a fixed tensile loading, the multi-axial generalization of material constitutive response takes the usual form by the Ramberg-Osgood nonlinear theory (Ramberg and Osgood, 1943). (10)ɛij/ɛ0=(1+ν)σij/σ0-δijνσkk/σ0+32α(σ¯/σ0)n-1Sij/σ0, where α is the hardening coefficient, δij the Kronecker delta, ν Poisson’s ratio; n is the hardening exponent with n = ∞ representing perfect plasticity and n = 1 linear elasticity; ɛ0 is the yielding strain and σ0 is the yielding stress with σ0=Eɛ0; Sij=σij-σkkδij/3 is the stress derivative, and σ¯=3sijsij/2 the effective stress.

Meanwhile, the Lagrangian density L may be viewed as a function of coordinates, displacements and total strain tensor. Accordingly, in the absence of inertia terms, it is defined by (11)L=L(xi,uk(xi),ɛkj(xi))=-V(xi,uk(xi))-W(xi,ɛkj(xi)).

The derivation of the material damage expansion force and the M-integral to be discussed can be deduced by subjecting the Lagrangian density moment to the divergence operation. The divergence of the Lagrangian moment is performed by (12)∇•(Lx)=(Lxi),i=mL+(∂L∂xi)explxi+∂L∂ukuk,ixi+∂L∂uk,juk,jixi where (∂L/∂xi)exp.denotes the explicit dependence of L on xi. The parameter m is denoted as m = xi,i, which is identical to 3 for three dimensions and 2 for two dimensions. Through the following discussions, it is always assumed that the body force fk is neglected in materials, i.e., V = 0. By using equations (5), (8) and (11), equation (12) reduces to (13)(Wxi),i=mW+(∂W∂xi)explxi+σjkuk,jixi.
Making using of the balance law equation (9), the last term of equation (13) can be written as (14)σjkuk,jixi=(σjkuk,ixi),j-σjk,juk,ixi-σjkuk,ixi,j=(σjkuk,ixi),j-σjkuk,j
Substituting equation (14) into equation (13) and rearranging arrive at (15)[Wxiδij-σjkuk,ixi],j=mW-σjkuk,j+(∂W∂xi)explxi.
By incorporating equations (3) and (4) into equation (15), the derived material balance is obtained as (16)Mj,j+Λ=0, with (17)Mj=Wxiδij-σjkuk,ixi+2-m2σjkuk, (18)Λ=-mWNL-(∂W∂xi)explxi.

We refer the term Mj as “material damage expansion force” similar as the definition of the Eshelby material forces and the term Λ as “material damage expansion source”, which originates from the material nonhomogeneity due to the existence of the defects in nonlinear elasticity.

It should be pointed that if the following assumptions are made: (i) The body force fk is neglected in materials, i.e., V = 0. (ii) The material is a homogeneous body without defects and the material constants are independent of xi, i.e., ∂W/∂xi = 0. (iii) The material possesses the linear elastic behaviors, i.e., WNL = 0. All damage expansion source terms will disappear (Λ = 0) and equation (16) reduces then to a conservation law (19)Mj,j=0,

It means that the damage expansion force will satisfy a similar balance law from a theoretical point as the resultant physical force in Newtonian mechanics for a complete material without any defects.

Nevertheless, for the nonlinear elasticity containing multiple defects, the assumptions (ii) and (iii) are violated and the material damage expansion force Mj would have the apparently physical meaning and in this way results in the well-known M-integral.

By integrating of divergence of material damage expansion force in the two-dimensional space (i.e., m = 2 in equation (17)), the definition of the M-integral can be originated as (20)M=∫AMj,jdA=∫A(Wxiδij-σjkuk,ixi),jdA (i,j,k=1,2) and transforming the area A integral into an associated contour Γ in 2D by the divergence theorem, the well-known definition of the M-integral are derived as (21)M=∮Γ(Wxjnj-Tkuk,ixi)dΓ (i,j,k=1,2). where Tk = σkjnj denotes the principle traction acting on the contour.

It is interesting to investigate the main contributions on the M-integral arising from in a nonlinear elastic damaged material. By integrating equation (16) over a region A, an alternative expression of the M-integral can be obtained by direct integration of the material damage expansion source (22)M=∫AMj,jdV=-∫AΛdV=∫A[mWNL+(∂W∂xi)explxi]dA.

Equation (22) demonstrates that the values of M-integral attribute to two kinds of sources. The first source is the material nonhomogeneity characterized by (∂W/∂xi)expl, which stems from the damages enclosed by the volume V. The contribution of damage on the M-integral is apparently understood and in this way the M-integral is able to be widely applied in defect mechanics to characterize the multiple defect stability and growth. The second source is mWNL, which stems from the nonlinear strain energy enclosed by the integral contour. Consequently, the contribution of the nonlinear strain energy has to be considered to evaluate the M-integral especially when the nonlinear material behaviors are considerable. The significant contribution of material nonlinear behavior on the M-integral will lead a set of quite different and intriguing features in contrast with those of the traditional M-integral in the linear elasticity where the nonlinear source terms just vanishes (WNL = 0).

sec.title: Physical interpretation of material damage expansion force
sec.p:
In this section, the physical interpretation of material damage expansion force is explored to indeed facilitate the understanding of the physical property of the M-integral to be discussed below. The explicit expressions will be derived for the relation of the damage expansion force and the change of the potential energy associated with the x1, x2-plane infinitesimal element motions in two-dimensional defect mechanics. The arguments can be extended to three-dimensional damage problems in a straightforward way. A self-similar expansion of the element with the unit thickness will be studied such that points (x1, x2) on the surfaces move with the distance of (λx1dt, λx2dt), where λ is the positive motion velocity and dt the time internal. Figure 1(a) and (b) depicts the transformation from the original element indicated by the solid black square into the expanded element by the dash red square along the x1 and x2 direction, respectively. The change of quantities on the element can be characterized by the stress, the associated displacement and the strain energy density during the self-similar expansions, where the stress components acting on the surfaces are assumed to remain constant throughout the element expansion. Figure 1.
Self-similar expansion one infinitesimal x1, x2-plane element (a) along x1-direction and (b) along x2-direction.

The energy changes will be calculated by considering the changes of strain energy and the work done by stresses on four surfaces S1, S2, S3 and S4, respectively. For the element motions along the x1 direction as shown in Figure 1(a), the change of internal strain energy due to self-similar expansion from x1 to x1–λx1dt on surface S1 can be calculated to be (23)ΔWS1=Wx1λdtdx2.
The change of work done by the stresses σ11 and σ12 on S1 is expressed as (24)ΔAS1=-σ11dx2[u1(x1-λx1dt,x2)-u1(x1,x2)]-σ12dx2[u2(x1-λx1dt,x2)-u2(x1,x2)]=(σ11u1,1x1+σ12u2,1x1)λdtdx2.

Thus, the change of potential energy by the self-similar expansion λx1dt on S1 is (25)ΠS1=ΔWS1-ΔAS1=(Wx1-σ11u1,1x1-σ12u2,1x1)λdtdx2=M1λdtdx2. where M1 denotes the first component of damage expansion force vector.

In the same way, the self-similar expansion of S3 is indicated from (x1 + dx1) to (x1 + dx1)(1 + λdt), the change of strain energy and the work done by stresses are therefore calculated by (26)ΔWS3=W(x1+dx1,x2)(x1+dx1)λdtdx2=(W+W,1dx1)(x1+dx1)λdtdx2+0(dx12dx2)=[Wx1+(W+W,1x1)dx1]λdtdx2+0(dx12dx2) and, (27)ΔAS3=(σ11+σ11,1dx1)dx2[u1((x1+dx1)+(x1+dx1)λdt),x2)-u1(x1+dx1,x2)] +(σ12+σ12,1dx1)dx2[u2((x1+dx1)+(x1+dx1)λdt),x2)-u2(x1+dx1,x2)]=(σ11+σ11,1dx1)dx2u1,1(x1+dx1,x2)(x1+dx1)λdt+(σ12+σ12,1dx1)dx2u2,1(x1+dx1,x2) ×(x1+dx1)λdt=(σ11+σ11,1dx1)(u1,1+u1,11dx1)λ(x1+dx1)dtdx2+(σ12+σ12,1dx1)(u2,1+u2,11dx1) ×λ(x1+dx1)dtdx2+0(dx12dx2)=[(σ11u1,1x1+σ12u2,1x1) +(σ11,1u1,1x1dx1+σ12,1u2,1x1dx1+σ11u1,11x1dx1+σ12u2,11x1dx1+σ11u1,1dx1+σ12u2,1dx1)] ×λdtdx2+0(dx12dx2)

From equations (26) and (27), the desired result of the change of the potential energy is arrived at (28)ΠS3=ΔWS3-ΔAS3=[Wx1-σ11u1,1x1-σ12u2,1x1 +(W+W,1x1-σ11,1u1,1x1-σ12,1u2,1x1-σ11u1,11x1-σ12u2,11x1-σ11u1,1-σ12u2,1)dx1]λdtdx2=(M1+M1,1dx1)λdtdx2.

Based on the explicit formalisms as shown in equations (25) and (28), it is instructive to conclude that the real physical meaning of the first component of damage expansion force vector is implied as the change of the potential energy of one infinitesimal element if the material points have the self-similar expansion along the x1-direction.

For the element motions along the x2 direction as shown in Figure 1(b), the straight manipulations can be made and the self-similar expansion of surface S2 from x2 to x2−x2λdt leads to the following change of strain energy, work and potential energy (29)ΔWS2=Wx2λdtdx1, (30)ΔAS2=-σ21dx1[u1(x1,x2-λx2dt)-u1(x1,x2)]-σ22dx1[u2(x1,x2-λx2dt)-u2(x1,x2)]=(σ21u1,2x2+σ22u2,2x2)λdtdx1, (31)ΠS2=ΔWS2-ΔAS2=(Wx2-σ21u1,2x2-σ22u2,2x2)λdtdx1=M2λdtdx1. where M2 denotes the second component of damage expansion force vector.

Finally, the self-similar expansion of S4 from x2 + dx2 to (x2 + dx2)(1 + λdt) leads to (32)ΔWS4=W(x1,x2+dx1)(x2+dx2)λdtdx1=(W+W,2dx2)(x2+dx2)λdtdx1+0(dx22dx1)=[Wx2+(W+W,2x2)dx2]λdtdx1+0(dx22dx1), (33)ΔAS4=(σ21+σ21,2dx2)dx1[u1(x1,(x2+dx2)+(x2+dx2)λdt)-u1(x1,x2+dx2)] +(σ22+σ22,2dx2)dx1[u2(x1,(x2+dx2)+(x2+dx2)λdt)-u2(x1,x2+dx2)]=[(σ21u1,2x2+σ22u2,2x2) +(σ21,2u1,2x2dx2+σ22,2u2,2x2dx2+σ21u1,22x2dx2+σ22u2,22x2dx2+σ21u1,2dx2+σ22u2,2dx2)] ×λdtdx1+0(dx22dx1) (34)ΠS4=ΔWS4-ΔAS4=[Wx2-σ21u1,2x2-σ22u2,2x2 +W+W,2x2-σ21,2u1,2x2dx2-σ22,2u2,2x2dx2-σ21u1,22x2dx2-σ22u2,22x2dx2 -σ21u1,2dx2-σ22u2,2dx2]λdtdx1=(M2+M2,2dx2)λdtdx1.

It is suggested from equations (31) and (34) that the physical interpretation of the second component of damage expansion force vector can be interpreted as the change of the potential energy due to the x2-direction self-similar expansion at a material point.

The present explicit formalisms in equations (25), (28), (31) and (34) do reveal that the damage expansion force vector can represent the change of the potential energy induced by the self-similar expansion of a material point.

sec.title: Physical interpretation of the M-integral
sec.p:
A straightforward physical interpretation of the M-integral for a multi-damage system can be made based on the present physical meaning of damage expansion force. As discussed earlier, the M-integral is associated with the integration of the damage expansion force along a close contour. If we calculate the M-integral over the specific contour Cs (s = 1, 2, … . . , N) only surrounding the sth defect, as shown in Figure 2 and the start and the end points of time t represent the initial non-damaged system and the current damaged system, the summation of M-integral over Cs would be associated with the total change of potential energy of the whole system, (35)∑s=1NM(s)(x1,x2)=CTPE/2, where M(s)(x1,x2) is defined along the specific contour enclosing the sth defect in the global coordinate system; CTPE=∫VΠdV denotes the change of the total potential energy due to the formation of defects in the whole system; the factor of 1/2 arises from the symmetric expansion of defect pattern. It is noteworthy that the finding presented here indicates that the summation of the M-integral around individual defects is inherently related to the half of CTPE of an ensemble of defects regardless of the material linear or nonlinear behavior. Figure 2.
Schematic of integral contours for calculating the M-integral.

Nevertheless, it should be reminded that the general definition of the M-integral is always defined along a closed contour enclosing all defects in the global coordinate system (x1, x2), e.g., Γ as shown in Figure 2. A natural question to ask at this point what is the physical meaning of the global M-integral. To answer that, it is useful to clarify an essential question, i.e., the dependence of the M-integral on the path selections in nonlinear elasticity. Only after doing so, could the physical interpretation of the M-integral be clarified.

By an explicit analysis, a detailed investigation of M-integral for two different path selections are performed where the first integral path Γ enclosing all defects and the second path ∑Cs with Cs only surrounding the s-th defect as schematically depicted in Figure 2. Here, we introduce the third path Ω denoted by Γ-∑Cs, which bypasses the defect zones and only encloses the homogeneity. Thus, the M-integral over path Ω is defined by: (36)MΩ=MΓ-∑M(s)=∮Ω(Wxini-Tkuk,ixi)ds.

By using Green's theorem, the first term ∮ΩWxinids in equation (36) can be written as (37)∮ΩWxinids=∮ΩWx1dx2-∮ΩWx2dx1=∫∫A(Ω)2Wdx1dx2+∫∫A(Ω)(∂W∂x1x1+∂W∂x2x2)dx1dx2, where A(Ω) means the area which is surrounded by the closed path Ω.
Making use of the stress equilibrium equation (9) with the absence of body force, the term ∂W∂x1x1 is formulated as (38)∂W∂x1x1=∂W∂ɛij∂ɛij∂x1x1=σij∂ɛij∂x1x1=σij∂∂x1(∂ui∂xj)x1=∂∂xj(σij∂ui∂x1)x1.
Similarly, (39)∂W∂x2x2=∂∂xj(σij∂ui∂x2)x2.
From equations (38) and (39), equation (37) can reduce to be (40)∮ΩWxinids=∫∫A(Ω)[2W+∂∂xj(σij∂ui∂xk)xk]dx1dx2.

Meanwhile, the second term ∮CTkuk,ixids in equation (36) can be written as: (41)∮ΩTkuk,ixids=∮Ωσk1uk,ixidx2-∮Ωσk2uk,ixidx1=∫∫A(Ω)(∂(σkjuk,i)∂xjxi+σkjuk,i∂xi∂xj)dx1dx2=∫∫A(Ω)[σijui,j+∂∂xj(σij∂ui∂xk)xk]dx1dx2.
Substituting equations (40) and (41) into equation (36), the M-integral integrated along the path Ω can be formulated as (42)MΩ=MΓ-∑M(s)=∫∫A(Ω)(2W-σijui,j)dx1dx2.

As discussed earlier, the strain energy density W can be separated into the linear and nonlinear parts in the nonlinear elastic material under a monotonic increasing loading. By incorporating equation (3) and (4) into equations (42), one of the most intriguing results of this paper can be arrived at (43)MΓ-∑M(s)=∫∫A(Ω)2WNLdx1dx2.

The results in equation (43) are able to demonstrate several features of the present analysis. First, if the area within Γ and ∑Cs possesses the purely elastic state i.e., WNL = 0, the discrepancies of two integrals mentioned in equation (43) will vanish and ensure the path-independence property of M-integral, i.e., MΓ=∑M(s). Otherwise, for the presence of nonlinear elastic zone in nonlinear elasticity, the values of the M-integral will be discrepant by the nonlinear elastic energy enclosed within two integral contour paths. In other words, the M-integral will be path-dependent when the integration contours are across or within the nonlinear zone. This is quite different from those in linear elasticity, where the M-integral is strictly path-independent. Due to the finding, a new physical interpretation of the global M-integral has to be reconsidered in nonlinear elasticity.

The other feature can be revealed by combining equations (35) and (43). The physical interpretation of the M-integral along the outside contour surrounding all defects can be established as (44)MΓ=CTPE/2+∫∫A(Ω)2WNLdx1dx2

The most significant conclusion may be made from equation (44). Providing the M-integral is evaluated by the closed contours enclosing all defects and there is no discontinuity outside the contour, the M-integral is equivalent to half of the decrease of CTPE during the formation of defects for the damaged solids with the addition of the non-negligible contribution from the nonlinear terms of the strain energy within the area enclosed by the contour. That is the real physical interpretation of the M-integral in nonlinear elasticity.

The new features of the M-integral regarding the path-dependence and the new physical interpretation have not been reported from the previous work. The present conclusions of the M-integral for a nonlinear elastic damaged material indeed facilitate the better understanding of the M-integral as a potential framework to evaluate material damage evolution of nonlinear elastic materials.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
The present study clarifies the physical interpretation of the M-integral by the explicit analysis in the nonlinear elasticity containing multiple defects. The conclusions can be summarized as follows:
The material nonhomogeneity induced by defects together with the nonlinear strain energy within the area enclosed by the integration contours will be the dominant contributions on the M-integral. The influence of the nonlinear strain energy will result in the path-dependence property of the M-integral.
The present explicit investigation reveals that the damage expansion force component associated with the M-integral is the change of the potential energy at a point of an elastic continuum due to a self-similar expansion in xi-direction of a unit surface.
The M-integral is inherently related to CTPE due to the formation of the defects with the addition of the nonlinear elastic strain energy within the area enclosed by the integral contours when accounting for the nonlinear material behavior. This finding of the present physical interpretation of the M-integral is quite different from those in linear elasticity, where the M-integral is only related to the CTPE.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China with grant No. 10932007 and No.11021202.

ChangJHPengDJ (2004) Use of M integral for rubbery material problems containing multiple defects. ASCE Journal of Engineering Mechanics 130(5): 589–598.

ChenYH (2001a) M-integral analysis for two-dimensional solids with strongly interacting microcracks. Part I: in an infinite brittle solid. International Journal of Solids and Structures 38(18): 3193–3212.

ChenYH (2001b) M-integral analysis for two-dimensional solids with strongly interacting microcracks. Part II: in the brittle phase of an infinite metal/ceramic bimaterial. International Journal of Solids and Structures 38(18): 3213–3232.
EischenJWHerrmannG (1987) Energy release rates and related balance laws in linear elastic defect mechanics. ASME Journal of Applied Mechanics 54(2): 388–392.
EshelbyJD (1951) The force on an elastic singularity. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A 244(877): 87–112.
EshelbyJD (1975) The elastic energy-momentum tensor. Journal of Elasticity 5(3–4): 321–335.
KienzlerRHerrmannG (1997) On the properties of the Eshelly tensor. Acta Mechanica 125(1–4): 73–91.
KingRMHerrmannG (1981) Nondestructive evaluation of the J and M integrals. ASME Journal of Applied Mechanics 48(1): 83–87.
KnowlesJKStermbergE (1972) On a class of conservation laws in linearized and finite elastostatics. Archive for Rational Mechanics and Analysis 44(3): 187–211.
MaLFChenYHLiuCS (2001) On the relation between the M-integral and the change of the total potential energy in damaged brittle solids. Acta Mechanica 150(1–2): 79–85.
McMeekingRM (1977) Finite deformation analysis of crack-tip opening in elastic-plastic materials and implications for fracture. Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids 25(5): 357–381.
NoetherE (1971) Invariant variational problems. Transport Theory and Statistical Physics 1(3): 183–207.
Ramberg W and Osgood WR (1943) Description of Stress-Strain Curves by Three Parameters. Technical Note No. 902. Washington, DC: National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.
RiceJR (1986) A path independent integral and the approximate analysis of strain concentration by notches and cracks. ASME Journal of Applied Mechanics 35(2): 379–386.
